awd_titl_txt: I-Corps: Surface-wave-based sensing of strength and stiffness of soft materials
awd_abstract_narration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this I-Corps project is the development of a robust and easily installed sensor module that delivers mechanical properties of soft materials in industrial processing lines. Materials that can deform visibly under small forces are classified as soft. Natural and synthetic soft materials such as rubber, foams, gels and biological tissues are ubiquitous in food production, structures, robots, 3D-printing, agriculture, pharmaceutical processing, and biomedical applications. Hence, the mechanical properties of soft materials are of primary interest to many industries. The development and deployment of the proposed sensor is immediately feasible for the soft food processing industry. When integrated to food processing lines, this sensor will provide high throughput real-time data to the production line managers and operators about strength, stiffness, texture, and consistency of the food being processed. This feedback will enable optimization of the processing settings and environment and thus will facilitate reduction of trim losses and online quality control of the processed food. Therefore, the proposed technology will help food waste reduction efforts of the food processors and manufacturers.  Natural expansion to biomedical, agricultural and polymer processing industries is possible as the innovation is scalable and adaptable to various soft materials and processing lines. 

This I-Corps project is based on the development of a surface-wave-based sensing method that delivers elastic and failure properties of soft materials. The sensing method is based on correlations between surface wave and mechanical properties: surface waves emitted during processing of soft materials are measured and analyzed, and estimated wave amplitude, energy and frequencies are correlated to the elastic and failure properties of soft materials. Measured properties (strength, stiffness, and toughness) deliver essential information on microstructure, texture, and consistency of soft materials. Therefore, this innovative sensing technique is broadly applicable to soft material processing industries. Initially, the sensing module will be adapted to the food processing industry. In this module, surface-waves emitted during cutting, slicing, peeling, and shredding of fruits, vegetables, cheese, meat, and meat substitutes will be monitored by non-contact optical sensors, and the elasticity and fracture properties of the products will be extracted from the surface-wave analyses. Those properties will provide online monitoring of product quality, processing conditions and operations. Such a monitoring system is currently missing in the food processing industry.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Technology, Innovation, and Partnerships

por.por_cntn:
The main objective of our program is to identify the market need for our vibration-based mechanical characterization technique during cutting/manufacturing/processing. For instance, cutting-induced vibrations are commonly seen in food, medical, polymer processing, semi-conductor and manufacturing industries. NSF I-corps project helped us interact with several professionals in those fields, identify their practical needs and see if our innovation can satisfy those needs. During the project we conducted 162 customer discovery interviews. Of those interviews, 106 were online or by phone and 56 were in-person through several expositions in the US. The evolution of our customer discovery process is as follows:

·       We began the I-corps program interviewing end users and decision makers in the above-mentioned industries. After those interviews, we found out that our characterization technique wasn’t a good fit for polymer processing, semi-conductor and manufacturing industries, and that it could benefit more directly to food and medical industries.

·       In the medical field, surgeons have a problem of quick and accurate diagnosis of malignancy of tissues during surgical operations called frozen examination. This issue is more prominent in hospitals in sub-urban and rural areas where access to modern biopsy technologies is limited. We anticipate our technology can address this issue through novel instrumented devices. However, many products in medical fields require several years of time to market due to federal regulations. Considering this, we have temporarily halted our work in the medical field. 

·       Then, we focused on the food cutting, processing and packaging industries for the rest of the I-corps program. We learned through our interviews that material losses constitute a major problem in the food processing such as cheese conversion, and protein and cereal bar manufacturing. Particularly in the cheese processing industry, trim losses and production downtime during cutting and slicing operations lead to major food waste and profit loss.

·       Considering the societal needs in reducing milk and cheese waste, we selected it as a customer segment for the rest of our program. We interviewed several people in the managerial level and operations line in the cheese making and processing industry. Besides, we interviewed cheese producers of various sizes: from boutique producers to large producers handling millions of pounds of cheese annually. 

·       We also interviewed manufacturers of cheese processing equipment. They reported that a large amount of cheese is lost during processing through trim losses, cheese lost on the floor, and losses due to sample weight laws and packaging. Current recovery methods like shredding are less profitable and result in undesired low-grade cheese.

·       From our interviews we found that cheese plants and equipment manufacturers are constantly investing in new technologies to develop automation for manufacturing and reduction in raw material losses. Cheese plants facing staffing challenges, lack of skilled labor, and rising costs are looking for automation solutions without a major overhaul of existing equipment.   

After identifying the market need, we proposed to develop a sensor prototype suited for cheese processing plants and obtained funding from the NSF PFI-TT program. We anticipate working on potential technology transfer and partnership agreements with equipment manufacturers or sensor companies that we interviewed during the NSF I-corps program. We anticipate that full integration of the sensor into the cheese processing lines will minimize the material loss issue, and thereby enhance quality control, profitability and sustainability.

 


Last Modified: 10/10/2024
Modified by: Corinne R Henak
por.por_txt_cntn:
The main objective of our program is to identify the market need for our vibration-based mechanical characterization technique during cutting/manufacturing/processing. For instance, cutting-induced vibrations are commonly seen in food, medical, polymer processing, semi-conductor and manufacturing industries. NSF I-corps project helped us interact with several professionals in those fields, identify their practical needs and see if our innovation can satisfy those needs. During the project we conducted 162 customer discovery interviews. Of those interviews, 106 were online or by phone and 56 were in-person through several expositions in the US. The evolution of our customer discovery process is as follows:


We began the I-corps program interviewing end users and decision makers in the above-mentioned industries. After those interviews, we found out that our characterization technique wasnt a good fit for polymer processing, semi-conductor and manufacturing industries, and that it could benefit more directly to food and medical industries.


In the medical field, surgeons have a problem of quick and accurate diagnosis of malignancy of tissues during surgical operations called frozen examination. This issue is more prominent in hospitals in sub-urban and rural areas where access to modern biopsy technologies is limited. We anticipate our technology can address this issue through novel instrumented devices. However, many products in medical fields require several years of time to market due to federal regulations. Considering this, we have temporarily halted our work in the medical field.


Then, we focused on the food cutting, processing and packaging industries for the rest of the I-corps program. We learned through our interviews that material losses constitute a major problem in the food processing such as cheese conversion, and protein and cereal bar manufacturing.Particularly in the cheese processing industry, trim losses and production downtime during cutting and slicing operations lead to major food waste and profit loss.


Considering the societal needs in reducing milk and cheese waste, we selected it as a customer segment for the rest of our program. We interviewed several people in the managerial level and operations line in the cheese making and processing industry. Besides, we interviewed cheese producers of various sizes: from boutique producers to large producers handling millions of pounds of cheese annually.


We also interviewed manufacturers of cheese processing equipment. They reported that a large amount of cheese is lost during processing through trim losses, cheese lost on the floor, and losses due to sample weight laws and packaging. Current recovery methods like shredding are less profitable and result in undesired low-grade cheese.


From our interviews we found that cheese plants and equipment manufacturers are constantly investing in new technologies to develop automation for manufacturing and reduction in raw material losses. Cheese plants facing staffing challenges, lack of skilled labor, and rising costs are looking for automation solutions without a major overhaul of existing equipment. 


After identifying the market need, we proposed to develop a sensor prototype suited for cheese processing plants and obtained funding from the NSF PFI-TT program. We anticipate working on potential technology transfer and partnership agreements with equipment manufacturers or sensor companies that we interviewed during the NSF I-corps program. We anticipate that full integration of the sensor into the cheese processing lines will minimize the material loss issue, and thereby enhance quality control, profitability and sustainability.
